Khan has accused the army and the current prime minister, Shehbaz Sharif, of being behind the assassination attempt he survived last November ‚Äì an allegation vehemently denied. In turn, the government has levelled a host of corruption charges against Khan. After Khan was ejected from office last year, the new regime claimed that while in government he had struck a quid pro quid deal with a big property tycoon in Pakistan causing a loss of more than $239m (¬£190m) to the national exchequer. Khan denies these allegations, which are part of a mounting effort by the government and military to ensure he cannot run for office again. On 9 May, Khan was arrested by almost 100 paramilitary officers as he attended a bail hearing for a corruption case. His party, PTI, called it an ‚Äúillegal abduction‚Äù and tens of thousands of Khan loyalists took to the streets in violent protest. Khan was held in custody until the police were forced to release him on 12 May, after the supreme court declared his arrest on court premises to be ‚Äúillegal and invalid‚Äù and he was granted bail. Khan returned home to Lahore and has since alleged that the country‚Äôs powerful military establishment was behind his arrest. The government says it will rearrest Khan as soon as the law allows. An Imran Khan supporter throws a stone towards police officers after setting fire to a pile of tyres during clashes in Islamabad. Photograph: AP What is the background to his arrest? Khan has more than 100 cases registered against him, on everything from sedition and corruption, to terrorism and even blasphemy. Whatever the full truth of the latest charges, there is little doubt his arrest is a politically motivated attempt to ensure he does not run for office again. Shaikh says this kind of subterfuge is nothing new in Pakistan. ‚ÄúCases being registered against politicians generally on charges of corruption is a game that all parties have played.‚Äù Khan himself has been accused of using this power against opposition leaders. How is Pakistan doing more generally? Pakistan is facing an economic crisis. Inflation has risen to 36.4%, meaning people cannot afford basic necessities including healthcare. Devastating floods last year submerged much of the country under water. Pakistan is on the edge of defaulting on its debt and is still waiting for a $1.1bn bailout from the IMF, which would have little impact on the $100bn total. Its usual backers, such as Saudi Arabia and other Gulf states, have not come forward with the kind of assistance offered in the past. Counterintuitively, the dire economic situation has been Khan‚Äôs political saviour. ‚ÄúDuring Imran Khan‚Äôs tenure in office the economy was tanking slowly, and much of that has to do with the fact that he had alienated all the political parties to such an extent that no one would help him deliver on his economic programme,‚Äù said Shaikh. ‚ÄúSo during his last year in office he saw his popularity plummet.‚Äù However, the failure of the government to resolve this crisis, which has become even more acute in the last year, has meant the blame has shifted to them. Shaikh said: ‚ÄúKhan is a very popular man at the moment, and if elections were to be held there is no doubt that he would come in with a huge majority.‚Äù Riot police take up position on the third day after the arrest of Imran Khan. Photograph: Bilawal Arbab/EPA What will happen next? This political and economic crisis threatens to tip Pakistan into a period of instability and unrest, although this is not inevitable. ‚ÄúStability can be restored, but that depends very much on political parties sitting together and resuming dialogue,‚Äù Shaikh said. The future of Pakistan‚Äôs already fragile democracy is at stake. Khan is demanding that both provincial and general elections take place soon, and has threatened mass protests if the ruling government does not agree to dates. Members of the ruling coalition have also begun their own protest against the supreme court, accusing it of bias towards Khan. Many fear that if the turmoil continues, the army will try to step in and take control, as has happened repeatedly in the past.

org.project.Article.webTitle: Turkey elections: runoff increasingly likely with Erdoƒüan ahead of Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu ‚Äì as it happened
org.project.Article.head: Turkey elections: runoff increasingly likely with Erdoƒüan ahead of Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu ‚Äì as it happened
org.project.Article.body: 11.08am BST We‚Äôre going to close this blog now. Here‚Äôs a brief summary of where things stand as we await official confirmation of the result: With nearly 99.5% of ballot boxes opened, Turkish president Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan has received 49.4% of votes his rival Kemal Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu 44.96%, Turkey‚Äôs elections council YSK has said. The near-complete results mean the election will almost certainly go to a runoff, scheduled for 28 May, since neither of the two leading candidates received more than 50% of the vote. Supporters of outgoing Turkish president Erdoƒüan cheer outside his AKP party headquarters as early results come through Photograph: √úmit Bekta≈ü/Reuters Supporters of outgoing Turkist president Erdoƒüan cheer outside the headquarters of AKP party in Istanbul Photograph: Francisco Seco/AP Updated at 6.41pm BST 6.03pm BST Opposition vice-presidential candidates Mansur Yava≈ü and Ekrem ƒ∞mamoƒülu have just given a press conference in the Turkish capital, Ankara, lashing out at the state news agency Anadolu for what they said was broadcasting distorted results. The opposition accuse Anadolu of broadcasting counted AKP votes first in a warped picture of the overall result, and say they are in the lead. The largest opposition party, the Republican People‚Äôs party (CHP) is running a parallel count by stationing their own observers at every ballot box and photographing every ballot as it is counted. ‚ÄúAccording to our results, with 23.87% of the votes counted, Kemal Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu is ahead,‚Äù said Yava≈ü, who is also Ankara mayor, adding: ‚ÄúThis data comes from all over Turkey and I can say that we are ahead in Istanbul and Ankara.‚Äù ƒ∞mamoƒülu, whose election as mayor of Istanbul in 2019 was a close race that was ultimately disputed by Erdoƒüan and re-run before he was declared the winner a second time, also directed his anger at Anadolu. ‚ÄúUnfortunately, we are still experiencing the scene we see in every election. Another case of Anadolu Agency [...] AA‚Äôs reputation is below zero,‚Äù he said. Presidential candidate Kemal Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu simply tweeted: ‚ÄúWe are ahead.‚Äù √ñndeyiz. ‚Äî Kemal Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu (@kilicdarogluk) May 14, 2023 Updated at 6.12pm BST 5.57pm BST Erdoƒüan's lead narrows with one-third of votes counted With more than a third (38.3%) of votes counted, according to the Anadolu state news agency (AA), the gap between the two leading candidates is shrinking. Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan now stands on 52.7%, his centre-left opposition rival Kamel Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu on 41.4%, and the nationalist Oƒüan on 5.4%. Updated at 7.33pm BST 5.51pm BST The main opposition Republican People‚Äôs Party (CHP) has said early results are looking positive for Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu. Faik √ñztrak, the party‚Äôs spokesperson, said in a televised speech: According to the data we received so far, we see the table very positively. When the number of ballot boxes opened reaches a meaningful figure, we will start to share the number of votes. Updated at 7.34pm BST 5.48pm BST The Guardian‚Äôs video team were on the ground in Turkey last week and produced a fascinating film about the importance of the Kurdish vote in these elections. Kurdish voters, many of them anti-Erdoƒüan, account for about 10-15% of the country‚Äôs electorate and their ballots could prove crucial. You can watch the film here: Updated at 5.49pm BST 5.37pm BST Underlining how important the big cities are to Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu‚Äôs vote share, Ruth Michaelson writes, the head of his CHP party in Istanbul and leading opposition figure Canan Kaftancƒ±oƒülu has just released a partial opposition parallel count in Istanbul. The move seems designed to calm anxious opposition voters as the count continues. ƒ∞stanbul‚Äôda saat: 19.17 itibariyle sandƒ±klarƒ±n %15 sisteme girdi ve %15 veriye g√∂re: Kemal Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu: % 51.33 R. Tayyip Erdoƒüan : % 43.94 Sinan Oƒüan : % 4.45 Muharrem ƒ∞nce : % 0.28#SanaS√∂z ü´∂ ‚Äî Canan Kaftancƒ±oƒülu (@Canan_Kaftanci) May 14, 2023 With 15% of the ballot boxes entered into the system in Istanbul, the vote stares stand at: Kemal Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu: 51.33% R. Tayyip Erdogan: 43.94% Sinan Oƒüan : 4.45% Muharrem ƒ∞nce : % 0.28 The vote in Istanbul is key as it is Turkey‚Äôs largest city, with more than 15 million residents out of 85 million in total. At least 64 million people were expected to cast their ballots across the country on Sunday. Updated at 5.56pm BST 5.24pm BST The Guardian‚Äôs Ruth Michaelson in Istanbul has this to say on the vote tally: Voters across Turkey are now glued to their television screens, watching results come in for what many are calling the most important election of the year. In some cases, people have travelled across the country to go back to their villages destroyed by powerful twin earthquakes earlier this year in order to cast their ballots, and turnout is expected to be unusually high. People everywhere reported unusually long wait times and long lines to vote. With the broadcast ban on the vote count now lifted, we‚Äôre now seeing results trickle in live, in an extremely tense vote that is expected to be close. Erdoƒüan has almost total control of the domestic media, which is affecting how we learn the latest results. Referring to the Anadolu Agency, a representative from the majority Kurdish Peoples‚Äô Democratic Party (HDP) to the electoral commission said: ‚ÄúThere is a great media manipulation. AA gets all the information from the government‚Äôs partners.‚Äù Ziya Meral of the Royal United Services Institute in London said: ‚ÄúWith all of its faults, yes it‚Äôs not a fair election, it‚Äôs decently free but not fully, given the overall conditions. But you can still select the candidate you want freely, so it‚Äôs substantially free from that perspective. Even for Erdoƒüan this vote matters so much, which goes to show this is a fundamental political battle for him.‚Äù 5.19pm BST Key event Just over 23% of votes have now been counted, according to state news agency Anadolu‚Äôs vote tracker. (Note that these are not official results. In past elections, Anadolu has been accused of favouring Erdoƒüan and his AKP party.) Vote shares stand at 54.6% for Erdoƒüan and 39.4% for Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu, with Oƒüan on 5.5%. Again, many of Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu‚Äôs votes are not expected to be reported until much later in the evening, while results from small rural polling stations that are mostly pro- Erdoƒüan tend to get counted first. Updated at 7.35pm BST 5.01pm BST As expected, Erdoƒüan leads in early results With just under 10% of votes counted, Turkey‚Äôs state Anadolu Agency reports that the incumbent president, Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan, holds an early lead with 59.5%. His arch-rival for the presidency, Kemal Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu, is on 34.8%, while the third candidate, nationalist Sinan Oƒüan, has just over 5% of votes counted so far. Analysts have said that Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu, who has relatively high levels of support in some of Turkey‚Äôs biggest cities, is likely to trail in early results but should pull back as more results come in. Updated at 7.36pm BST 4.52pm BST Opposition leader Kemal Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu has asked election officials on Twitter not to leave the ballot boxes until the last vote was delivered. Demokrasi kahramanlarƒ±mƒ±za seslenmek istiyorum. ƒ∞mzalƒ± son sandƒ±k tutanaƒüƒ± teslim edilene kadar, ne olursa olsun asla sandƒ±klarƒ±n ba≈üƒ±ndan ayrƒ±lmayƒ±n. Millet iradesinin tam ve doƒüru bi√ßimde tecelli etmesi sizin kararlƒ±lƒ±ƒüƒ±nƒ±za baƒülƒ±. G√∂receksiniz, yorgunluƒüunuza deƒüecek. ü´∂üèº ‚Äî Kemal Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu (@kilicdarogluk) May 14, 2023 ‚ÄúI want to call out to our heroes of democracy. Never leave the ballot boxes, no matter what, until the last signed ballot box report is delivered,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe full and correct manifestation of the will of the people depends on your determination. You will see, it will be worth your tiredness.‚Äù 4.46pm BST Results reporting ban lifted; early lead for Erdoƒüan expected As of 6.30pm local time, Turkey‚Äôs supreme election board has lifted its ban on the reporting of election results ‚Äì originally in place until 9pm. Results should now start trickling in, more than two hours before they were initially expected. The picture is is likely to remain unclear for some hours yet, however. That‚Äôs essentially because results from Erdoƒüan‚Äôs rural and conservative heartland tend to be declared early, while Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu‚Äôs strong urban support comes through later. Analysts have said they expect an initial lead for Erdoƒüan that should be clawed back by Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu in the course of the evening. Updated at 6.08pm BST 4.42pm BST The election campaign has been dominated by the state of Turkey‚Äôs economy and the country‚Äôs cost of living crisis, as well as the massive damage caused by February‚Äôs earthquakes. Even before the earthquakes Turkey‚Äôs economy was in trouble: economists say Erdoƒüan‚Äôs unorthodox insistence on keeping interest rates low has sent inflation soaring ‚Äì to 85% last year ‚Äì while the Turkish lira has lost about 80% of its value against the dollar in the past five five years. Soaring food prices and rents have been among voters‚Äô biggest concerns throughout the campaign. Interest rates are usually hiked to cool inflation, but Erdoƒüan has denounced them as ‚Äúthe mother and father of all evil‚Äù. The opposition has also successfully attacked alleged government mismanagement of the rescue operation after the earhquakes, which killed more than 50,000 people and displaced millions more. The slow pace of reconstruction, as well as accusations of a failure to enforce building codes owing to widespread corruption, are also believed to have hit Erdoƒüan‚Äôs suport, particularly in the hard-hit, traditionally pro-AKP east and south-east of the country. Updated at 7.36pm BST 4.30pm BST Deniz Barƒ±≈ü Narlƒ± in Istanbul writes in with some news on turnout, which could prove crucial to the election‚Äôs outcome: Election turnout is expected to be high in this pivotal election. Turkey has a fairly high turnout rate generally: it was around 86% in the previous presidential elections in 2018. ‚ÄúWe are expecting a record turnout in Istanbul, and there are also reports that this is the same across Turkey,‚Äù said Canan Kaftancƒ±oƒülu, the Istanbul chair of Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu‚Äôs CHP party. Istanbul is Turkey‚Äôs biggest city and turnout here may be decisive for the election results as the race is expected to go down to the wire. ‚ÄúExcept for one or two individual cases, I would say that our citizens completed the voting process without any trouble or problem,‚Äù Kaftancƒ±oƒülu said. She also invited voters to go to polling stations to observe the vote-counting process, regardless of the party they voted for. Voting was also being monitored by a mission from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which is due to deliver a preliminary statement on its findings on Monday. Updated at 4.32pm BST 4.20pm BST The news portal Haberler has posted an amusing video clip of two voters waiting patiently to cast their ballots in Istanbul who suddenly realise their president is standing in the queue right behind them: Cumhurba≈ükanƒ± Erdoƒüan'ƒ± arkasƒ±nda g√∂ren se√ßmen ≈üa≈üƒ±rdƒ±. pic.twitter.com/QymY2oEax9 ‚Äî Haberler.com (@Haberler) May 14, 2023 Updated at 6.15pm BST 4.15pm BST Reuters has pulled together the views of a range of Turkish voters from around the country as they cast their votes on Sunday: In Istanbul, Hasibe, 40, a school employee: Erdoƒüan gave us everything. He made many lovely things happen. I don‚Äôt know what else he can give us but I want him to continue. We‚Äôve been worn about by the excitement all week. I don‚Äôt think it will go to a runoff. Ahmet Kalkan, retired health worker, 64: I see these elections as a choice between democracy and dictatorship. I chose democracy and I hope that my country chooses democracy. I have hope that Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu will win. Kubra, 36, telecommunications sector worker: I have voted many times but I feel so excited for the first time. I voted for Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu and the Nation Alliance. I want development and change in education, law, democracy and human rights. Gungor Yucel, 80: My ideas have changed since the last election. We feel insulted now. We are tired of the constant sayings and empty words. Of course, there are good things Erdoƒüan did, but lately, they started to look down on and insult the nation. In the southern city of Antakya, devastated by February‚Äôs earthquake, Ozgur Kayabolen: We don‚Äôt like this government, especially this president. When the earthquake happened, they leave here the people for dead, nobody come here for four days. In Diyarbakir, in the mainly Kurdish southeast, Nuri Can, 26: I voted for the Green Left Party and Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu because the economic crisis is making it difficult for us. A change is needed for the country. After the election there will be an economic crisis at the door again, so I wanted change. Hayati Arslan, 51: I voted for the AK Party and Erdoƒüan. The country‚Äôs economic situation is not good but I still believe that Erdoƒüan will fix this situation. Turkey‚Äôs prestige abroad has reached a very good point with Erdoƒüan and I want this to continue. 3.47pm BST The Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan, has tweeted to his supporters after polling stations closed: Deƒüerli dava ve yol arkada≈ülarƒ±m... Oy verme i≈ülemi √ºlkemiz genelinde, hamdolsun, demokrasimize yakƒ±≈üƒ±r bir ≈üekilde tamamlandƒ±. ≈ûimdi, her zaman olduƒüu gibi sandƒ±klara sƒ±kƒ± sƒ±kƒ±ya sahip √ßƒ±kma vakti. Sonu√ßlar kesinle≈üinceye kadar milletimizin iradesini korumaya devam!.. ‚Äî Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan (@RTErdogan) May 14, 2023 ‚ÄúThe voting process has been completed throughout the country in a way that befits our democracy,‚Äù the outgoing president said. ‚ÄúNow, as always, it is time to firmly protect the ballot boxes. Until results are finalised, we continue to protect the will of our nation.‚Äù Updated at 4.32pm BST 3.37pm BST Emre Peker, an analyst at EurasiaGroup, has an interesting thread on Twitter here on what the election is ultimately about and how it could play out: Ultimately, this is an election battle between continuity and change, with the economy the biggest driver. Erdogan is desperately trying to move the debate to issues such as terrorism/national security and family values, while trying to project a strong-world-leader image. But given the scale of economic problems, he is not having much luck‚Äîtherefore resorting to handouts to woo voters.Kilicdaroglu is doubling down on sound economic management, democracy, justice, rule of law, and freedoms. His coalition is performing well on the campaign, outshining Erdogan with painting a pretty picture for the future, compared to Erdogan‚Äôs reliance on past accomplishments. Peker suggests neither Erdoƒüan nor Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu may be able to decisively push past the 50% threshold to avoid a runoff ‚Äî but he reckons a surprise win is within reach all the same. ‚ÄúThe vote will be a knife-edge,‚Äù he said. Updated at 4.34pm BST 3.27pm BST Today‚Äôs election matters far beyond the borders of Turkey. Under Erdoƒüan, the country has flexed is military muscle in the Middle East and beyond, launching incursions into Syria, waging an offensive against Kurdish militants inside Iraq and sending military support to Libya and Azerbaijan. It has also clashed diplomatically with Saudi Arabia, Egypt, the United Arab Emirates and Israel, rowed with Greece and Cyprus over maritime boundaries in the eastern Mediterranean, and been subjected to US arms industry sanctions after buying Russian air defences. Erdoƒüan‚Äôs closeness to Russia‚Äôs president, Vladimir Putin, has led critics to question Turkey‚Äôs commitment to its fellow Nato members, which Ankara‚Äôs recent reluctance to endorse Sweden and Finland‚Äôs membership applications has only reinforced. Turkey also, however, brokered a deal for Ukrainian wheat exports ‚Äì underlining its potential role in ending the war. For the EU, defeat for Erdoƒüan would be strategically welcome but politically tricky, since it might relaunch Turkey‚Äôs accession bid. 3.23pm BST Here are some agency photographs of today‚Äôs voting in Turkey Turkey‚Äôs president for the past 20 years, Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan, casts his vote in Istanbul Photograph: Dia Images/Getty Images Opposition candidate Kemal Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu casts his ballot at a high school in Ankara Photograph: Alp Eren Kaya/Depo Photos/ZUMA Press Wire/Shutterstock Election workers start the count after polling closes in Ankara Photograph: √áaƒüla G√ºrdoƒüan/Reuters Voters in Istanbul line up to cast their ballots earlier in the day Photograph: Chris McGrath/Getty Images Updated at 3.25pm BST 3.04pm BST Polls close It is now 5pm in Turkey and voting has ended in both the country‚Äôs parliamentary and presidential elections. Under Turkish law, reporting of any results is banned until 9pm local time. By later this evening we should have a good indication of whether either presidential candidate has cleared the 50% bar necessary to avoid a runoff in a fortnight‚Äôs time. Updated at 3.05pm BST 3.01pm BST Kemal Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu, 74, has headed the main opposition Republican People‚Äôs party (CHP) since 2010 and was named the six-party opposition alliance‚Äôs presidential candidate in March. Long stuck in Erdoƒüan‚Äôs shadow, the bookish former civil servant, from a historically repressed Kurdish group, has lost half a dozen national elections to Erdoƒüan while leading his secular party. He entered parliament in 2002 with the CHP, which was established by modern Turkey‚Äôs founder Ataturk, and ‚Äì although he has led the CHP to major victories in big-city municipalities including Istanbul, Ankara and ƒ∞zmir ‚Äì has struggled to reach beyond its secularist grassroots to attract conservative voters. The candidate of the Nation Alliance or Table of Six has been criticised as lacking charisma, and for blocking politicians from his own party ‚Äì such as high-profile mayors ‚Äì who may have stood a better chance of victory. During this campaign, however, Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu has struck a more inclusive note, seeking to draw in voters disillusioned by Erdoƒüan‚Äôs rhetoric and perceived economic mismanagement. He has promised economic prosperity, and greater respect for human rights and the rule of law. His frank kitchen chats with voters have belatedly turned him into something of a social media star. He has also promised to retire after stripping the presidency of Erdoƒüan‚Äôs powers and then ‚Äúgo and spend more time with my grandchildren‚Äù. Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu‚Äôs promise to ‚Äúbring spring ‚Ä¶ and serenity to this land‚Äù has attracted younger voters as well as a broad cross-section of Turks exhausted by the outgoing president‚Äôs culture wars and harsh, polarising rhetoric. He has also pledged to release many of the popular figures jailed by Erdoƒüan‚Äôs government in the wake of a failed but bloody 2016 coup attempt as part of his objective of ending what he has called the president‚Äôs ‚Äúone-man regime‚Äù. Updated at 3.08pm BST 2.44pm BST The country‚Äôs most powerful leader since Atat√ºrk, who founded modern Turkey a century ago, Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan, a devout 69-year-old, has steered Turkey steadily away from secularism, glorifying its Islamic past - and embracing chaos on the way. He rose to power 20 years ago as prime minister while Turkey was emerging from a period of rampant inflation, promising sound government, and became president in 2014. At the height of his success, Turkey enjoyed a protracted economic boom. But economists blame Erdoƒüan for the country‚Äôs current economic crisis, saying his insistence on low interest rates has sent inflation soaring ‚Äì to 85% last year ‚Äì and caused the Turkish lira to lose 80% of its value against the dollar in five years. Erdoƒüan has logged more than a dozen election victories and survived an attempted coup in 2016, shaping the country to his vision of a pious, conservative society and assertive regional player. In 2018 he abolished its parliamentary system, centralising power in an executive presidency. From his 1,000-room palace outside Ankara, Erdoƒüan in effect dictates government policy and, critics say, has eroded democracy, stifling dissent and bringing media and judges under his sway. His supporters argue he has saved the country from serious security threats. Abroad, Turkey under Erdoƒüan has flexed its military muscle in the Middle East and beyond, launching offensives in Syria and squabbling incessantly with Greece. His interventions in Libya and Nagorno-Karabakh swung the outcomes of complex great-power conflicts. His courtship of Russia has upset Washington, and his sale of weapons to Ukraine has irritated the Kremlin. But he has always seemed to know how to play one off the other so as to appear like the consummate statesman to his domestic audience. Updated at 3.40pm BST 2.22pm BST Ruth Michaelson and Deniz Barƒ±≈ü Narlƒ± are in Istanbul for the Guardian. Ruth has just sent this early dispatch on the atmosphere as Turks went to the polls: The mood at some of the polling stations in Istanbul was sharply divided, with AKP voters stating they were determined to re-elect Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan and rebuffing concerns about the economy or the risk he could lose. Many mentioned a need for the country to remain united despite the deep political polarisation that has overtaken Turkey throughout the past decade and fears that Erdoƒüan or his Justice and Development party (AKP) could demand people take to the streets if they lose, or if the vote is close. ‚ÄúWe will do what justice and fairness require,‚Äù said 51-year-old Veysel Isinal, asked if he would take to the streets if the AKP demanded it. ‚ÄúI believe the president will win re-election ‚Äì if he doesn‚Äôt that would be bad for the country.‚Äù Younger voters, however, were determined to vote for anyone other than Erdoƒüan or the AKP. A group in their mid-20s standing in the middle of Erdoƒüan‚Äôs home district in Istanbul, where he campaigned just yesterday, said gen Z would be the generation to end his 20-year reign. Kurdish voters, courted by the opposition leader Kemal Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu, were jubilant about the prospect of ending Erdoƒüan‚Äôs reign. ‚ÄúThis time he‚Äôs going,‚Äù one said, laughing happily with several friends who had turned out to vote. Updated at 3.12pm BST 2.16pm BST The basics: who is standing, and how do the votes work Turkey‚Äôs president, Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan, and his Justice and Development party (AKP) face their greatest political challenge yet. Amid an economic crisis, and months after earthquakes killed more than 50,000 people and displaced millions more, today‚Äôs elections ‚Äì presidential and parliamentary ‚Äì will decide who leads the country where it heads next. Erdoƒüan has championed religious and conservative social values at home, while asserting Turkey‚Äôs influence in the region and loosening its ties with the west. Kemal Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu of the secularist Republican People‚Äôs party (CHP), is standing for the six-party Nation Alliance. He has pledged to prioritise justice, corruption and education. In the presidential election, any candidate who wins more than 50% of votes in the first round is elected president. If no one secures a majority, the election goes to a runoff ‚Äì due on 28 May ‚Äì between the two leading candidates. In the parliamentary elections, the number of seats a party wins in the 600-member parliament is directly proportional to the number of votes it receives, providing it gets ‚Äì alone or as part of an alliance ‚Äì at least 7% of the national vote. Updated at 2.17pm BST 1.58pm BST The year's most important election? Hello and welcome to the Guardian‚Äôs live coverage of what many of the world‚Äôs media and pundits have had no hesitation in describing as the most significant election of 2023. It‚Äôs easy to see why: Turkey‚Äôs president, Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan, leader for the past 20 years of a country of global economic and strategic importance, could be on the way out. Polls increasingly show Kemal Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu, the unity candidate for six opposition parties, with a narrow lead over Erdoƒüan ‚Äì possibly scoring above the 50% needed to win outright. Over two decades, an increasingly authoritarian Erdoƒüan has taken control of many of Turkey‚Äôs institutions ‚Äì including much of the media and judiciary ‚Äì steadily sidelining his opponents. Kƒ±lƒ±√ßdaroƒülu aims to reverse many of those policies, including Erdoƒüan‚Äôs all-powerful executive presidency, return power to parliament, slash inflation and improve relations with the west. The stakes are high: Turkey, a country of 85 million people at the crossroads between Asia, Europe and the Middle East, could continue its democratic slide, or reverse the damage. We‚Äôll be bringing you all the latest news as it happens: polls close an hour from now, at 5pm local time (2pm GMT), and we could have an early indication of the result by 9pm local time.

org.project.Article.webTitle: Carlos Alcaraz stunned by world No 135 Fabian Marozsan in Italian Open
org.project.Article.head: Carlos Alcaraz stunned by world No 135 Fabian Marozsan in Italian Open
org.project.Article.body: The qualifier Fabian Marozsan produced the biggest shock of the ATP season so far with a stunning 6-3, 7-6 (4) victory against the second seed Carlos Alcaraz in the third round of the Italian Open on Monday afternoon. Marozsan, a 23-year-old Hungarian ranked No 135, is the lowest‚Äëranked player to defeat Alcaraz since July 2021. Until he came through the qualifying draw in Rome and defeated the No 67 Corentin Moutet, Marozsan had never won an ATP match. Related: Andrey Rublev: ‚ÄòI lost them matches because of myself. I couldn‚Äôt handle the pressure‚Äô He had additionally arrived in Rome in poor form. Although Marozsan won an ATP Challenger event on clay in March, he started this tournament having lost five of his previous six matches. Alcaraz, meanwhile, had a 30-2 record in 2022 after tournament wins in Barcelona and Madrid and the 20-year-old will return to No 1 in the ATP rankings next week. Despite his disappointment, Alcaraz absorbed the defeat with a typical smile, heaping praise on his opponent‚Äôs performance after the match. Asked if he felt any physical issues, Alcaraz shrugged off the question: ‚ÄúNo, no, no. I was perfect physically,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI just didn‚Äôt feel comfortable. He made me feel uncomfortable on court. He was aggressive all the time. He was playing inside the baseline all the time. It was tough for me to get into the match, into the rally.‚Äù The defeat may prove a blessing in disguise for Alcaraz, who will have a chance to rest instead of toiling through a second two-week Masters 1000 event ahead of the French Open, where he will be seeded No 1 at a grand slam for the first time. For Marozsan, his victory moves him up to around 114 in the ATP rankings, meaning he is very close to directly entering his first grand slam main draw. ‚ÄúThe goal for me was winning one match in the qualies. Now I just won five matches,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm very, very happy,‚Äù Marozsan said. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt imagine this one. It was my dream last night.‚Äù On his first appearance on any major stadium court, Marozsan approached the most hyped and in‚Äëform player on the tour without fear or favour. From the very beginning of the match, Marozsan served precisely and controlled the baseline. He forced Alcaraz back with consistent aggression and his sweet two-handed backhand while offering the Spaniard a taste of his own medicine: a constant stream of winning drop shots. As Marozsan commanded the opening set, Alcaraz struggled to find his range. He continued to spray unforced errors, eventually falling down a set and a break. But Alcaraz fought hard, retrieving the break at 3-4 by landing returns and finding greater consistency, and he eventually forced a tie-break. Just as it seemed that Alcaraz had steadied himself, establishing a 4-1 lead in the tie-break, Marozsan exploded. He won the final six points of the match with an array of absurd winners from difficult defensive positions. Marozsan attacked until the end, forcing a final forehand error from Alcaraz as he completed the victory of his life. ‚ÄúI just tried to do something special, win a few games and maybe a set,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI just beat the world No 1, he‚Äôs the best in our sport, so I‚Äôm really happy with this.‚Äù Meanwhile, Daniil Medvedev continued to find his feet on clay as he moved into the fourth round with a 3-6, 6-1, 6-3 victory against Bernab√© Zapata Miralles of Spain. Medvedev has reached at least the round of 16 of all three clay court Masters 1000 events this year and his progress has been clear. ‚ÄúThis year, I feel different, I feel like I can play on clay,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI can play well. I can put my opponents in trouble. It‚Äôs just, well, don‚Äôt miss, don‚Äôt double fault and that‚Äôs how you can win matches.‚Äù

org.project.Article.webTitle: The biggest ever space explosion has occurred ‚Äì what do you mean you don‚Äôt care? | Rhiannon Neads
org.project.Article.head: The biggest ever space explosion has occurred ‚Äì what do you mean you don‚Äôt care?
org.project.Article.body: Something pretty huge happened in space recently. Well, that‚Äôs not strictly true ‚Äì to be more accurate, something truly gargantuan happened in space approximately 8 billion years ago, that we are only just finding out about now. Last Friday, scientists revealed the largest cosmic explosion ever witnessed: like a supernova, but more than 10 times brighter and more powerful than any other seen before. And its cause? A giant cloud of gas being sucked into a supermassive black hole. If you want people to be excited about something, it‚Äôs important to come up with a catchy name. So, taking a leaf out of Elon Musk‚Äôs book of baby names, scientists called it AT2021lwx. But I‚Äôm gonna call her Sue. Sue Pernova. (You‚Äôre welcome.) Sue had humble beginnings. She started out like the damp patch in the corner of your bathroom ‚Äì small and barely noticeable, then over the course of time growing into something monstrous and without precedent. It was only when scientists established just how distant Sue was (8 billion lightyears) that they realised quite how much energy she must be burning to produce a light so bright. This is all well and good, I hear you cry, but why should I care? Sue seems great, but she lives miles away and besides I‚Äôm far too busy having to do the weekly shop, picking up the kids from school and Googling ‚Äúblack mould removal‚Äù. Well, I‚Äôve been a space superfan since I was old enough to say ‚ÄúHouston we have a problem‚Äù, so you don‚Äôt have to convince me to care. But space can give us an insight into our existence. There are certain aspects of space exploration that are easy to defend. Like the Dart mission last year which successfully tested technology designed to shift an asteroid off its course, protecting Earth and its inhabitants from a fatal collision. Most of us have a vested interest in the Earth not being smashed to smithereens, so it‚Äôs great to know that Nasa is on the case. Related: Astronomers capture largest cosmic explosion ever witnessed Some of the other stuff, though, is far more abstract and, for want of a better word, nerdy. But the truth is, every time something like this happens it puts another piece in the puzzle of understanding where we came from and where we will go. We all know some basic things about the universe and our solar system from our school days: Jupiter has its raging stormy eye, Saturn has its rings, and Pluto has an identity crisis about its latest reclassification. But what you perhaps didn‚Äôt know, because they only found out recently, is that Saturn didn‚Äôt always have its rings. A study from the University of Colorado suggests that the rings are only 400 million years old, with Saturn being nearer 4.5 billion years in age. Those figures are quite hard to get your head around, but if you scale that timeline down, it‚Äôs the equivalent of an 85-year-old bloke called Stanley deciding to grow a mo-hawk at 81. That‚Äôs a pretty wild and late-stage development, right? Certainly not something to define his whole existence by. In the even blinkier-blink of an eye that is the period of human existence, we happen to have magically coincided with this beautiful phenomenon. Us being here now at the same time of Saturn‚Äôs rings is a delightful coincidence: a reminder that everything is fleeting, everything is changing, even in the universe. Someone sent me a meme recently with a picture of the galaxy and an arrow pointing to a barely visible dot labelled ‚ÄúYou, crying in the shower‚Äù. Apart from being very funny, it‚Äôs also very true (the crying bit, certainly). I find the underlying message of it weirdly profound. We are all so very small and the universe is so very big and almost all of our hopes, dreams and fears are entirely trivial. If that doesn‚Äôt sound particularly comforting, stick with me. In 2009, Nasa released captures from the Hubble telescope showing the deepest image of the universe ever taken to date, allowing you to scroll in and out of hundreds of galaxies and solar systems that seemingly go on for ever. If you ever need a moment of profound perspective, that does it. Cosmically speaking, if we are all insignificant, then everything we do is almost in defiance of that. It renders the choices we make simultaneously meaningless and also the most wonderful act of living; one more beautiful addition to an already improbable existence. That‚Äôs a pretty liberating thought. It‚Äôs all connected. Like it or not, we‚Äôre all part of a kind of celestial foxtrot: expanding, contracting, dying and being reborn. So next time you hear about something happening a million miles away, think about how you‚Äôre a small part of that and how incredible it is to exist. Why not look out of your window tonight ‚Äì maybe you‚Äôll see the light from some supernova long since gone. And who knows, perhaps someone 8 billion lightyears away will be looking back from their damp, damp, bathroom, seeing the dead light from our sun and wondering about their own place in the universe. Rhiannon Neads is a writer and actor

org.project.Article.webTitle: Share a tip on your favourite coastal walk ‚Äì you could win a holiday voucher
org.project.Article.head: Share a tip on your favourite coastal walk ‚Äì you could win a holiday voucher
org.project.Article.body: We all know walking is good for body, mind and soul. Add views of the sea into the mix and it‚Äôs even better. Whether it‚Äôs a multi-day hike in a wild landscape or a saunter along the beach at sunset, tell us about what makes your chosen walk special and about any highlights en route. org.project.Article.webTitle: Doyle Brunson, the ‚ÄòGodfather of Poker‚Äô, dies at age of 89
org.project.Article.head: Doyle Brunson, the ‚ÄòGodfather of Poker‚Äô, dies at age of 89
org.project.Article.body: Doyle Brunson, one of the most influential poker players of all time and twice world champion, died on Sunday at the age of 89. Brian Balsbaugh, Brunson‚Äôs agent, posted a statement on Twitter from the family. ‚ÄúIt is with a heavy heart we announce the passing of our father, Doyle Brunson,‚Äù the statement read. ‚ÄúHe was a beloved Christian man, husband, father and grandfather. We‚Äôll have more to say over the coming days as we honor his legacy. Please keep Doyle and our family in your prayers. May he rest in peace.‚Äù Related: Doyle Brunson Brunson started playing seriously in Fort Worth, Texas, where he said the game was far tougher than the glossy, televised tournaments that are prevalent today. ‚ÄúIt was like the old west. Violence was rampant,‚Äù he told the Guardian in 2005, adding he had seen two people shot during games. ‚ÄúIt was kind of a hangout for the hoodlums and gangsters of Texas and it was very, very volatile.‚Äù Brunson, called the Godfather of Poker and also known as ‚ÄúTexas Dolly,‚Äù won 10 World Series of Poker tournaments ‚Äì second only to Phil Hellmuth‚Äôs 16. He also captured world championships in 1976 and 1977 and was inducted into the Poker Hall of Fame in 1988. He won more than $6m in live earnings during his career. He wrote Super System in 1979, one of the first books to delve into poker strategy. It created a lasting impact that professional and casual players used to improve their performances. ‚ÄúThe two most important things are a good sense of recall and a good understanding of people,‚Äù Brunson said when asked about the secret to success in poker. ‚ÄúYou have to have a sixth sense, a kind of gut feeling that tells you what the other guy‚Äôs holding. That‚Äôs probably the thing that all the greats share.‚Äù Tributes poured in from other poker players after Brunson‚Äôs death was announced. Five-time WSOP winner Scotty Nguyen tweeted that he ‚Äúcan‚Äôt believe this day has come ‚Äì you will always be held high in our hearts, the man, the myth, the legend & THE GODFATHER of poker baby! Mr Brunson, you made poker what it is baby! thank you for what you give to all of us baby! RIP Mr Doyle Brunson THE GODFATHER OF POKER.‚Äù Brunson continued to play at a high-level well into his 80s and said poker helped him feel young. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt stop playing because we get old, we get old because we stop playing,‚Äù Brunson said on a number of occasions. Rest in Peace to the Biggest Legend of Them All. Thank you for being the consummate player and gentleman. No one will ever fill your seat. pic.twitter.com/riE35PCrQh ‚Äî WSOP - World Series of Poker (@WSOP) May 15, 2023 Brunson is survived by his wife, Louise, and children Todd and Pamela. Todd followed in his father‚Äôs footsteps, becoming a professional poker player and is also a member of the Poker Hall of Fame. ‚ÄúThe plan was for [Todd] to be a lawyer,‚Äù Brunson told the Guardian in 2005. ‚ÄúHe was in this third year of college and I didn‚Äôt even know he played poker. Then he came home one summer and declared he was going to turn professional. His mother was very angry about it. And I pretended to be.‚Äù

org.project.Article.webTitle: ‚ÄòI used to do tarot readings but it got too scary‚Äô: Sting on making Shape of My Heart
org.project.Article.head: ‚ÄòI used to do tarot readings but it got too scary‚Äô: Sting on making Shape of My Heart
org.project.Article.body: Sting, singer, songwriter The guitarist Dominic Miller and I would get together at my house in Wiltshire every Wednesday. One week, Dom came in with four chords. I said, ‚ÄúI like the sound of that‚Äù ‚Äì and eventually we had the shape of a song. I took it out into the garden on headphones and just walked around thinking, ‚ÄúWhat is the story this music is trying to tell?‚Äù The chords weren‚Äôt sexy ‚Äì they were contemplative. So I was thinking of somebody who uses their brain. I came up with the idea of a card-player who is also a philosopher. As a kid, I had played five-card stud. Years later, someone taught me tarot and I would do readings for people and see all this dark stuff I was apprehensive about telling them. In the end, it got so scary I gave it up, but I remained fascinated by tarot cards and their relationship with regular playing cards ‚Äì the diamonds are pentacles and the spades are swords. So for the song, I liked the imagery of a kind of soldier whose weapons are his cards. The hook ‚Äì ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs not the shape of my heart‚Äù ‚Äì reflects the fact that a playing card heart doesn‚Äôt look like a human one. ‚ÄòWe didn‚Äôt dress it up too much‚Äô ‚Ä¶ Sting. Photograph: Eric Ryan Anderson By that point, I had spent a lot of time in airless studios and I just wanted to come home. So I built a studio in the kitchen. The atmosphere on the record came from that environment ‚Äì we were all very happy, and the house was reverberating with music. In the video, I‚Äôm walking the dog. I asked the legendary harmonica player Larry Adler if he‚Äôd play on it. The guy had recorded Gershwin‚Äôs Rhapsody in Blue and had a piece ‚Äì Romance for Harmonica ‚Äì written for him by Vaughan Williams. It was such an honour that he agreed. David Sancious played keyboards and Vinnie Colaiuta drums. We didn‚Äôt dress it up too much. It‚Äôs been sampled many times by rap artists: I think the descending chords inspire a contemplative kind of rap. When I hear Craig David or Juice WRLD‚Äôs versions, I think they‚Äôve interpreted the song in the same way. In my set now, we do Shape of My Heart and Juice WRLD‚Äôs version as a mashup. There‚Äôs even a magician called Shawn Farquhar who plays the song as he shuffles cards. Every time a certain card is mentioned in the lyrics, it miraculously appears at the top of the deck. I‚Äôve watched his video several times. I‚Äôm fascinated by all the places where the song turns up. Dominic Miller, guitarist, songwriter When I auditioned for Sting in 1989, I couldn‚Äôt get any sound out of my guitar. Technicians were running around, changing amps, switching power supplies. I stood there thinking: ‚ÄúThis is really going to shit.‚Äù Then, after they‚Äôd exhausted every possibility, Sting casually walked over and turned the volume up on my instrument. The crew were in hysterics ‚Äì but thinking I‚Äôd already lost the gig helped me relax. We‚Äôve played together ever since. The Shape of My Heart riff wasn‚Äôt something I intended to present to him. I was just playing around with some Chopin-esque descending piano chords as an exercise, but they were really nice. So, instead of naffly trying to make it sound classical, I came up with a series of notes for the right hand with a John Lennon type of rhythm. It‚Äôs been sampled many, many times ‚Äì and there are something like 150 covers I was sitting by Sting‚Äôs fireplace in Lake House playing it. Only the dog was listening, but then Sting said, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs that, mate?‚Äù I told him it was just my silly little riff and he said, ‚ÄúThat should be a song.‚Äù We put a simple beat together on a drum machine and he went out to the garden and came back with a lyric, but I didn‚Äôt really hear the words at that point. I drove home and didn‚Äôt think more about it. We had 30-40 ideas for songs. Then later he called and said: ‚ÄúThat thing we were working on today sounds really good.‚Äù It was the fifth single from the album Ten Summoner‚Äôs Tales, but people started taking more notice of it after Luc Besson used it in the film L√©on. Since then, it‚Äôs been sampled many, many times ‚Äì and there are something like 150 covers. The 90bpm tempo and descending chord sequence seem to connect with a certain type of producer. It amuses me that people like Juice WRLD, Nas, Craig David and the Sugababes are actually playing Chopin without realising it. ‚Ä¢ On 18 May, Sting will become an Ivors Academy Fellow, the highest honour the Academy bestows. Message in a Bottle, a dance theatre production by Kate Prince, is on tour across the UK and internationally); Sting‚Äôs My Songs world tour arrives in the UK on 24 June.

org.project.Article.webTitle: Sunday Mirror ‚Äòdid dodgy stuff‚Äô on every story, phone-hacking trial told
org.project.Article.head: Sunday Mirror ‚Äòdid dodgy stuff‚Äô on every story, phone-hacking trial told
org.project.Article.body: The Sunday Mirror‚Äôs editor personally taught journalists how to hack voicemails, a former reporter has told the high court. Dan Evans told the phone-hacking trial that illegal activity was ‚Äúbog-standard‚Äù at the tabloid newspaper. ‚ÄúThe paper did dodgy stuff on basically every story and that is how we operated,‚Äù he said. Andrew Green KC, the Mirror‚Äôs barrister, suggested that Evans‚Äôs recollection of events might be affected by the reporter‚Äôs heavy consumption of alcohol and drugs while working on the Sunday Mirror. Evans replied: ‚ÄúThat would be common to pretty much everyone else who worked on those newspapers.‚Äù Evans was giving evidence in support of Prince Harry and other alleged phone-hacking victims, who are suing Mirror Group Newspapers. They claim illegal behaviour was widespread at the Daily Mirror, Sunday Mirror and People and was approved by top executives including Piers Morgan. Morgan has denied all wrongdoing. The reporter said he was the victim of ‚Äúcorporate grooming‚Äù in the dark arts of journalism, after joining the Sunday Mirror as a junior reporter in the early 2000s. Evans said he was taught to systemically hack celebrities‚Äô voicemails by the Sunday Mirror‚Äôs then boss, Tina Weaver, and the news editor Nick Buckley, with the knowledge of the newspaper‚Äôs lawyers. The journalist says he was made the Sunday Mirror‚Äôs dedicated phone hacker in 2003 after the previous occupant of the role left to join another newspaper. Evans then acted under the ‚Äútutelage and instruction‚Äù of Weaver and Buckley to build a phone-hacking database, with other journalists at the Sunday Mirror feeding him celebrities‚Äô personal mobile phone and landline numbers to be hacked. These numbers were stored on a PalmPilot, enabling Evans to systematically access the celebrities‚Äô voicemails in the hope of finding stories about their personal lives. The court has already heard allegations that Weaver, a former showbusiness correspondent, was personally involved in illegally accessing voicemails during the 2000s. She was arrested on suspicion of phone hacking along with other senior Mirror staff in 2013 but the case was dropped two years later, after the Crown Prosecution Service concluded there was ‚Äúinsufficient evidence to provide a realistic prospect of a conviction‚Äù. Phone hacking involved calling an individual‚Äôs phone number and attempting to guess the pin code that provided remote access to voicemails. Most people did not change the default four-digit code, making it easy for journalists to listen in on what was in their inboxes. Evans, who went on to work for the News of the World, later admitted hacking phones and carrying out other illegal acts. He was given a suspended sentence after giving evidence against Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson at their phone-hacking trials in 2014. The reporter told the court that the Sunday Mirror regularly used private investigators to illegally ‚Äúblag‚Äù private records by phoning up organisations and persuading people to hand over personal details. Weaver allegedly ordered Evans to stop using one private investigator ‚Äúnot because it was illegal‚Äù but because she feared the individual would leak confidential tips and stories to a rival newspaper. Evans denied his evidence to the phone-hacking trial was driven by a desire to pursue a personal vendetta and said he was tired by his involvement in phone hacking. ‚ÄúIt has been a bane on my life,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been extremely stressful. I‚Äôve committed to seeing through an important process.‚Äù He said illegal behaviour was ‚Äúdeeply entrenched‚Äù at the company. Mirror Group Newspapers, which has already paid out more than ¬£100m to settle phone-hacking claims, is disputing much of the evidence in this trial and argues that the claimants have waited too long to bring their cases. The case continues.

org.project.Article.webTitle: Chelsea‚Äôs new monsters, bench depth and other Women‚Äôs FA Cup final lessons | Suzanne Wrack
org.project.Article.head: Chelsea‚Äôs new monsters, bench depth and other Women‚Äôs FA Cup final lessons
org.project.Article.body: Hybrid monsters After Chelsea had navigated their way past Bayern Munich in 2021 to earn a place in their first Champions League final, Emma Hayes labelled her gutsy side ‚Äúmentality monsters‚Äù. They then lost the final against Barcelona by a humbling 4-0 scoreline. But the ‚Äúmentality monsters‚Äù moniker stuck and has been reaffirmed in three consecutive FA Cup wins and back‚Äëto-back Women‚Äôs Super League titles, with a third in sight. After beating Manchester United 1-0 to win the FA Cup at Wembley on Sunday, Hayes had a new label for her side. ‚ÄúWhat the team has become is the most flexible team,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúOur team has become ‚Äòhybrid monsters‚Äô. We can float between things in ways that takes years to master. They are so adaptable.‚Äù Winning in transition There are always incomings and outgoings, but football teams exist in cycles, with the core peaking and then being pulled apart as the side is reshaped for the next phase. Chelsea are in transition. The team have had to cope for much of the season without the forwards Fran Kirby and Pernille Harder and the summer signing Kadeisha Buchanan forced the captain, Magda Eriksson, out of the side in the early stages of the season. But it is ongoing, with Harder and Eriksson out of contract at the end of the season and courting offers and Kirby‚Äôs injury and illness record meaning Chelsea always need a plan B. Despite the turmoil, they are still winning and that is what makes these victories more impressive. After their triumph on Sunday, Hayes spoke of her aim during periods of change. ‚ÄúOur team has been in transition,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe had six different players in the starting lineup to last year‚Äôs final. That, for me, is a sign of real progress. My big thing is: ‚ÄòHow can we keep winning while transitioning?‚Äô To win knowing we‚Äôre in that stage, this is far and away my most memorable FA Cup final.‚Äù Emma Hayes lifts the FA Cup after her team‚Äôs victory at Wembley. Photograph: Clive Rose/Getty Images Depth and bench ‚ÄúManchester United had the first half but we had the second half,‚Äù Hayes said. United could rue missed chances and not capitalising on their first‚Äëhalf dominance but it was in the second that the game turned. The change was easy to pinpoint. In the 57th minute, Harder and the midfielder Sophie Ingle replaced Jessie Fleming and Melanie Leupolz and the momentum shifted decisively in Chelsea‚Äôs favour. When United‚Äôs brightest threat, Nikita Parris, exited a few minutes later, with the forward Rachel Williams coming on, the Reds faded. The later introductions of the forwards Lucia Garc√≠a and Martha Thomas underwhelmed. That is the difference between the sides. Chelsea don‚Äôt just have incredible high‚Äëquality depth in their squad, they have players on the bench with many minutes under their belts. ‚ÄúAll the time in training, we don‚Äôt play starting groups, we believe in different combinations, different relationships and everyone that knows me knows I don‚Äôt put together a team of 11 players ‚Äì it‚Äôs about a squad,‚Äù Hayes had said before the final. That is the level United need to reach. The starting XI is strong, but Marc Skinner‚Äôs lack of rotation this term has frustrated a layer of the fanbase. It is costly not only because those players don‚Äôt get a rest but also because the transition of players in and out of the XI is not smooth. Convincing Alessia Russo and Ona Batlle, whose contracts are up this summer, to stay will be vital for United alongside strengthening the squad. But will players be enticed to the club if playing time is limited? Not even Champions League football will be enough to lure players if they won‚Äôt play. Is this the Kerr World Cup? There is no doubting Sam Kerr‚Äôs phenomenal talent and drive. Her 10th goal in seven domestic cup finals is testament to the Australian‚Äôs potency. Kerr has been the figurehead of Chelsea‚Äôs more bruising charge towards the double this season, a role she has shared in recent years with Harder and Kirby. The return of Harder, who has four goals and an assist in two league games since her comeback from injury and set up Kerr for the winning goal in the final, speaks to how much has been put on Kerr‚Äôs shoulders. She has looked knackered but Harder‚Äôs availability is allowing her much‚Äëneeded rest. The World Cup starts in July and Kerr is the tournament‚Äôs poster woman. Australia have had their share of injuries this year, with Arsenal‚Äôs Caitlin Foord and Steph Catley, San Diego Wave‚Äôs Emily van Egmond, Melbourne Victory‚Äôs Elise Kellond‚ÄëKnight, Tottenham‚Äôs Kyah Simon and Aston Villa‚Äôs Emily Gielnik among those who missed their most recent training camp. Some will return, some won‚Äôt, but what has been clear this season is that if Kerr is there anything can happen no matter who is around her or what the odds are.

org.project.Article.webTitle: George Osborne to lead ¬£2.4bn investment management firm
org.project.Article.head: George Osborne to lead ¬£2.4bn investment management firm
org.project.Article.body: George Osborne has been hired to lead a new $3bn (¬£2.4bn) investment management firm, adding to a growing roster of lucrative jobs the former UK chancellor has taken up since stepping down as an MP in 2017. Osborne, who led the Treasury under David Cameron from 2010 to 2016, has been appointed chair of Lingotto Investment Management, which is owned by the billionaire Agnelli family‚Äôs Exor group. Exor manages the Italian family‚Äôs investments in an array of companies, including Juventus FC, the Economist and Ferrari, and is run by the Agnelli heir, John Elkann. Related: Ban smoking and tax fruit juice, says George Osborne Lingotto markets itself as ‚Äúan independent, entrepreneurial‚Äù firm that will allow staff to pursue their ‚Äúpassion for investing without the bureaucracy of most large organisations, or the loneliness of standalone funds‚Äù. It adds to a growing list of City roles held by Osborne, who is already a partner at the boutique City advisory firm Robey Warshaw. That role, which he took up in early 2021, has already proved lucrative, with the former politician having been one of four partners who shared a ¬£26.5m payout last year. He will also remain a director for his family‚Äôs wallpaper-making business, Osborne & Little, which is controlled by his father, Sir Peter Osborne. The company disclosed last year that it had increased pay for directors, including the former chancellor, by 30% after a jump in profits that were helped by ¬£700,000 in British and US government grants. The ex-parliamentarian will also maintain his roles as chair of the British Museum and managing partner of the venture capital firm 9yards Capital, which he founded with his younger brother, Theo. The firm has made a number of investments in startups including the US-based cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase ‚Äì which recently reached a settlement with US authorities after an investigation into compliance and money-laundering controls ‚Äì and Robinhood, the trading platform that gained notoriety for allowing amateur stock investors to play the market. Osborne had an even more wide-ranging portfolio career before he agreed to give up many of those positions when joining Robey Warshaw two years ago. He said goodbye to a big annual paycheque from BlackRock, which paid him ¬£650,000 for working one day a week as an adviser. Previous posts he had held also included his editorship of the Evening Standard ‚Äì which he led between 2016 and 2019 ‚Äì and his chairmanship of the Northern Powerhouse Partnership. The new role at Lingotto is new but not unexpected, with Osborne already having served as the chair of Exor‚Äôs business advisory council for the past five years. Lingotto ‚Äì which is not disclosing Osborne‚Äôs salary ‚Äì said the former chancellor would drop the council role to run the investment management firm, but would ‚Äúuse his extensive professional experience in support of the company‚Äôs development‚Äù. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm delighted to be joining the team here, which offers something new and unique in the investment management space,‚Äù Osborne said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a privilege to chair the Exor partners‚Äô council since 2018 and I now look forward to working with the Lingotto team, helping them to build a great company.‚Äù Lingotto has also hired former Baillie Gifford partner James Anderson to its investor team. It brings Anderson back into the industry a year after he stepped down from Baillie Gifford, where he was an early backer in firms including Amazon, ByteDance and Tesla, and helped deliver returns of 1,155% for his actively managed fund between 2000 and 2022.

org.project.Article.webTitle: Swiss academic Tariq Ramadan goes on trial accused of rape
org.project.Article.head: Swiss academic Tariq Ramadan goes on trial accused of rape
org.project.Article.body: The prominent Swiss academic and Islam scholar Tariq Ramadan has gone on trial in Geneva on charges of rape and sexual coercion. The 60-year-old told the court he denied allegations that he carried out an attack on a Swiss woman in a Geneva hotel in 2008. Ramadan was a professor of contemporary Islamic studies at the University of Oxford before taking a leave of absence in 2017 when rape allegations were first made against him by French women, in what was seen as the biggest repercussion of the #MeToo movement in France. He has also denied those allegations. The complainant in the Swiss case, who had converted to Islam in her youth, was 40 at the time of the alleged attack. She says she has faced threats and therefore wishes to be known under the assumed name of ‚ÄúBrigitte‚Äù during the trial. She said she had met Ramadan at a book signing in Geneva and later at a conference. They had corresponded via social media. A few months later he had invited her for coffee at his hotel after a conference. Ramadan is charged with three counts of rape against Brigitte in his hotel room on 28 October 2008, and one count of sexual coercion. Ramadan is accused of subjecting her to brutal sexual acts as well as beatings and insults. Ramadan, who could face up to 10 years in prison, denies all charges and told the court he was innocent. He said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here because I‚Äôm going to fight,‚Äù and denounced what he called ‚Äúlies and manipulation‚Äù against him. He told the court he had multiple sclerosis and was currently receiving a monthly payment from Oxford. ‚ÄúThis trial is an ordeal for my client, not therapy,‚Äù the Swiss complainant‚Äôs French lawyer, Fran√ßois Zimeray, told AFP. ‚ÄúShe is waiting for recognition of the suffering that she has lived with for 15 years and which she has made it a painful duty to reveal. She expects a difficult, painful confrontation but she is ready for it, convinced that this fight is a duty for her as much as an ordeal.‚Äù The Swiss woman had filed a police complaint in Geneva after French women spoke to the media about alleged rapes by Ramadan in hotels in France. The French state prosecutor last year called for Ramadan to stand trial in France for the alleged rapes of four women between 2009 and 2016. It will fall to French investigating judges to rule whether those cases should go to trial. Ramadan was arrested in France in 2018 and spent nine months in prison on remand over the French rape allegations before being released on probation and barred from leaving the country. He was given exceptional authorisation to attend the Geneva trial this week. In recent years, Ramadan had repeatedly said allegations of rape against him in France and Switzerland were a politically motivated plot and that he had been the victim of bias in the French justice system. The academic, who had advised successive British governments on Islam and society, denied all allegations. The three-day trial in Geneva will be heard by a panel of judges who will return a verdict on 24 May.

org.project.Article.webTitle: Police hunt suspects after more than a dozen cars set alight in Dorset
org.project.Article.head: Police hunt suspects after more than a dozen cars set alight in Dorset
org.project.Article.body: Police are hunting suspected arsonists who caused havoc when they set fire to 13 cars in usually peaceful Dorset neighbourhoods. The apparently random incidents in suburbs of Poole and Wimborne Minster took place over a three-hour period and led to 65 calls to the fire service. Residents in one street were awoken at 1.20am to find four vehicles ablaze. One woman was so frightened that she and her two young daughters fled their home in their pyjamas, fearing the flames would spread from her car to the building. The cars affected included a Nissan Micra, Fiat Panda, BMW X5 and an Audi A1. One witness, Poppy Baker, 57, a credit controller, said: ‚ÄúAt about 1.30am I saw this orange glow from my window. A Ford Ka was burning and there was so much heat the paint on my front door was melting. ‚ÄúThe car belongs to a mother and she ran out the house in her pyjamas with her two young daughters. The fire engulfed the car very quickly. I‚Äôm told a man had been seen running away from a fire and someone said they saw a man jumping on the back of a motorbike. Everyone is in shock.‚Äù Maggie Stirrup, 70, said: ‚ÄúI was woken up with my husband at around 2am. We looked out the window and saw our neighbour‚Äôs car on fire. It was right next to our door and my husband is in a wheelchair. I didn‚Äôt know how we would get out if it spread.‚Äù Darren Trickett, 60, whose Land Rover Discovery was destroyed, said: ‚ÄúI woke up when I heard a bang, I didn‚Äôt know what was happening. I looked out the window and saw my car in flames. I was worried that the engine might explode. Local residents described the scene as ‚Äòlike a war zone‚Äô. Photograph: Jesse Bartlett/PA ‚ÄúI ran out of the house to try to get the fire extinguisher from the boot but the central locking wouldn‚Äôt work. I just stood and watched. I just can‚Äôt believe it happened here.‚Äù Chloe Torring, whose Nissan car was burnt out, said: ‚ÄúMy neighbour woke me up and I saw my car burning and I just couldn‚Äôt believe it. Why would someone do something like this?‚Äô Kayleigh Humphires, 33, said: ‚ÄúThe night sky was just glowing orange. It‚Äôs like a war zone out there today, there are so many burnt out cars.‚Äù The first blaze was reported in Wentworth Drive in Broadstone, a suburb of Poole, at 11.35pm, before three cars were torched on Oakley Hill, Merley, on the outskirts of Wimborne, at 1.08am. At 1.20am, fire crews were called to New Borough Road in Wimborne to reports of four cars alight. The suspects then moved on to Poole Road where they torched two more vehicles at 1.24am and at 1.35am set fire to another car on the road, which spread to a home. The rampage ended with two cars being set ablaze on Merley Ways, Poole, at 2.26am. DS Simon Austin of Dorset police appealed for people with any CCTV that may have captured the arsonists to come forward. He said: ‚ÄúThese incidents have affected a large number of victims in the wider Wimborne area and we are aware that this will cause concern.‚Äù A Dorset and Wiltshire fire service spokesperson said: ‚ÄúBetween 11.30pm yesterday and just before 2.30am, our service control centre received approximately 65 999 calls about vehicle fires in the Wimborne and Poole areas.‚Äù

org.project.Article.webTitle: Thailand‚Äôs opposition parties start alliance talks after voters reject military rule
org.project.Article.head: Thailand‚Äôs opposition parties start alliance talks after voters reject military rule
org.project.Article.body: Thailand‚Äôs opposition parties have secured by far the largest number of votes in national elections, delivering a damning verdict to the military-backed government that has ruled for nearly a decade. Move Forward, a progressive opposition party popular with young Thais, surpassed expectations by winning the most votes and seats and said on Monday that it was ready to form a government. Its leader, Pita Limjaroenrat, told media he had invited Pheu Thai, the party associated with the exiled former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra, and four other opposition parties to form an alliance. ‚ÄúI am Pita Limjaroenrat, the next prime minister of Thailand,‚Äù he said in Bangkok, vowing to be a ‚Äúprime minister for all‚Äù. Pheu Thai later confirmed it had agreed to Pita‚Äôs proposal to form an opposition coalition. Related: Young Thais look to Pita Limjaroenrat to bust military-royalist grip on power For any of the opposition parties to take power, they will need to form a coalition that has numbers strong enough to pass through a system that is weighed in favour of the military-backed candidates. A future prime minister will be voted on not just by the 500-seat house of representatives, whose membership is be dictated by the election results, but also by the senate, whose 250 members were appointed by the military after the last coup. It is unclear if senators‚Äô votes will reflect the will of the people, especially given Move Forward‚Äôs ambition to reform Thailand‚Äôs lese-majesty law. Pita Limjaroenrat warned of a ‚Äúhefty price‚Äù to pay if there was interference in the election outcome that would lead to the formation of a minority government. The election commission chair, Ittiporn Boonprakon, said Move Forward had secured 151 of the 500 available seats, while Pheu Thai had 141. The numbers would need to be confirmed before they could be pronounced as official, which would happen within 60 days. He said voter turnout was the highest recorded, at 75.22%. Supporters of the Move Forward party react to the election results. Photograph: Sirachai Arunrugstichai/Getty Images Prayut Chan-ocha, a former army chief who first came to power in a coup in 2014, and who ran a staunchly nationalist campaign, was trailing far behind with 36 seats. However, this is sufficient for him to still be in the running for prime minister, in the event he can cobble together a coalition. Move Forward, which wants to reform the lese-majesty law ‚Äì a taboo topic ‚Äì and has taken a strong stance in calling for military reform, shocked even some of its own supporters by outperforming expectations on Sunday. Throughout the national count, it was neck and neck with Pheu Thai, a heavyweight opposition party that had been aiming to win by a landslide. Over the past two decades, parties linked to the Shinawatra family have repeatedly proved unbeatable at the ballot box, winning the most seats in every election since 2001. Thitinan Pongsudhirak, a professor at Chulalongkorn University in Bangkok, described the results as ‚Äústaggering‚Äù and ‚Äúhistoric‚Äù. Pheu Thai had campaigned using its old approach of populist policies, he said. ‚ÄúMove Forward takes the game to the next level with institutional reform. That‚Äôs the new battleground in Thai politics.‚Äù This was the first election in which the lese-majesty law was openly discussed by candidates ‚Äì a change brought about by the 2020 youth-led mass protests where activists risked jail to call for the influence and wealth of the monarchy to be curbed. Move Forward, whose own candidates have been charged under the law, is the only party to make a clear commitment to reforming it. Pheu Thai said the matter should be discussed in parliament but is strongly opposed to the law being scrapped, while Conservative parties all fiercely oppose any change. Pita, 42, a former executive of a ride-hailing app, said: ‚ÄúThe sentiment of the era has changed and it‚Äôs right. And today it‚Äôs a new day and hopefully it‚Äôs full of bright sunshine of hope going forward.‚Äù Related: Thailand elections: young people want radical change in a country they say is stagnating A joint session of the House of Representatives will be held with the Senate in July to select the new prime minister. It is unclear how senators will vote. Somchai Sawangkarn told Reuters, that any candidate ‚Äúmust be honest and not cause problems in the country. Hitler was elected in a majority but led the country to world war ‚Ä¶ If there is a possibility of creating division in the country, I will not vote for them.‚Äù Opposition candidates could also face court cases that could prevent them from staying in power. Move Forward is the reincarnation of Future Forward, an equally outspoken party that performed well in the 2019 election and was closed down by the constitutional court the following year, after it was accused of breaking funding rules. Last week, a complaint was filed against Pita, claiming he owned undeclared shares in a media company. He has denied any wrongdoing. Complaints have also been filed against Pheu Thai. On Sunday, Prayuth slipped away quietly from his United Thai Nation party headquarters, where there were few supporters to be seen. ‚ÄúI hope the country will be peaceful and prosper,‚Äù Prayuth said. ‚ÄúI respect democracy and the election. Thank you.‚Äù Reuters and Agence France-Presse contributed to this report

org.project.Article.webTitle: West Ham to appoint director of football in attempt to fix transfer shortcomings
org.project.Article.head: West Ham to appoint director of football in attempt to fix transfer shortcomings
org.project.Article.body: West Ham are set to appoint a director of football in an attempt to address misgivings over their recent transfer strategy. A recruitment process is under way and changes are expected at the club this summer. Potential candidates have been identified and include the former Liverpool sporting director Michael Edwards, Monaco‚Äôs Paul Mitchell, Brentford‚Äôs Lee Dykes and Atalanta‚Äôs Lee Congerton. There have been discussions with Victor Orta, who recently parted company with Leeds, but the Spaniard is regarded as an unlikely appointment. Related: Mbeumo and Wissa guide Brentford to victory against distracted West Ham West Ham, who are yet to decide whether to keep David Moyes as manager, have endured a disappointing campaign despite spending close to ¬£160m on players last summer. Control over signings was largely handed to Moyes. Sources have spoken of dissatisfaction within the hierarchy over the club‚Äôs business. If Moyes stays it is anticipated his influence over transfer business would be reduced. Moyes would have to decide whether he is willing to work with a director of football. Moyes is close with Rob Newman, the head of recruitment. Questions are set to be raised over Newman‚Äôs role. West Ham, six points above the bottom three, have been battling against relegation despite their outlay. It is felt that bringing in a director of football would help the sporting director, Mark Noble. The former captain was appointed in January and the board are impressed with how he has settled. It has been recognised, though, that there is not enough support or experience around Noble. West Ham want to bolster their scouting network and relieve the demands on Noble, who is expected to have a large say over the academy. West Ham had a director of football when Mario Husillos joined in 2018. Husillos was heavily associated with the then manager, Manuel Pellegrini, and left when the Chilean was fired in December 2019. The latest search for a director of football is being led by David Sullivan, West Ham‚Äôs largest shareholder. Sullivan has reached out to intermediaries and remains the most influential figure at the club. The co-owner will take charge of finding a manager if Moyes leaves. Moyes‚Äôs future could depend on whether West Ham win the Europa Conference League. They are 2-1 up before the second leg of their semi-final at AZ Alkmaar on Thursday. Moyes could earn himself another season if he brings West Ham their first major trophy since 1980. Winning the Conference League would also earn qualification into the Europa League. There is disquiet over how West Ham have fared in the league. They are not safe from relegation after losing to Brentford on Sunday and there have been complaints over the style. West Ham are monitoring Graham Potter, Brendan Rodgers and Celtic‚Äôs Ange Postecoglou. There are indications that Paulo Fonseca will spend another season at Lille. At least one other candidate is lurking in the background. West Ham had hoped to kick on after finishing seventh last season. Moyes and Newman were handed significant funds and chased a number of targets but the spending has produced mixed results. The biggest disappointment has been the ¬£35.5m Italy striker Gianluca Scamacca, from Sassuolo. Scamacca, who has struggled to settle, has three league goals and is out for the season with a knee injury. Flynn Downes, Emerson Palmieri, Thilo Kehrer and Maxwel Cornet have also struggled to live up to expectations, and Alphonse Areola is yet to displace Lukasz Fabianski as the No 1 goalkeeper. There has been more encouragement from the Morocco defender Nayef Aguerd, who joined for ¬£29.8m. Lucas Paquet√° has produced flashes of class in midfield since becoming West Ham‚Äôs record buy at ¬£51.5m from Lyon. But West Ham will need more hits than misses this summer given that they are likely to lose Declan Rice. The midfielder is attracting heavy interest from Arsenal and Manchester United. West Ham hope to receive at least ¬£100m for Rice but they would need to spend the money wisely.

org.project.Article.webTitle: London woman, 95, unable to use breathing machine due to persistent home flooding
org.project.Article.head: London woman, 95, unable to use breathing machine due to persistent home flooding
org.project.Article.body: A 95-year-old woman receiving palliative care has been left unable to use her breathing equipment due to power cuts caused by persistent flooding at her council-run house. Asabu Laher, who lives in Clapham, south London, is bed-bound, blind and suffering from organ failure. She is receiving end-of-life support at the home she shares with her three children, who have learning difficulties. Laher‚Äôs family say the house floods monthly, causing power outages ‚Äì and that they first flagged the issue a year and a half ago. The flooding, which started more than 30 years ago, is partly due to damage to the external drains caused by tree roots. ‚ÄúThey did tanking [the application of a coating] around the walls in the basement many years ago now. But ‚Ä¶ the problem has returned. It is ruining the foundations of the property and the main electricity has stopped working with the amount of water in there. Over time, the foundations will become soft and the building may collapse,‚Äù said Laher‚Äôs grandson Maajid Patel. He added the council sends a company around to drain the water after it floods, although the company does not always arrive. However, he claims there has been no attempt to address what is causing the deluge. ‚ÄúWe have said if you cannot be bothered to fix the leak in the basement then at least bring mains electricity points upstairs [to avoid power outages],‚Äù he said. On 3 May, the water level in the basement reached 73cm, causing a total power outage to the entire house. It meant Laher could not use the machine that helps her with breathing. All the refrigerated food also spoiled. Her family phoned the council at midday, her grandson said, but nobody showed up to fix the issue after an initial appraisal at 2pm. ‚ÄúI called Lambeth again at 7pm to chase it up and was told by two colleagues that they were due to come out for the repair. By this point my grandmother was struggling to breathe already as she hadn‚Äôt had access to her oxygen tank for the entire day,‚Äù Patel said. ‚ÄúUnfortunately, as we expected, nobody came and at 11pm we had to put my grandmother in a taxi and pull her out of her home and into our house in Streatham so we could provide her with working electricity for her oxygen machine.
